title: Boris Johnson could face prison if he snubs probe into relationship with Jennifer Arcuri
text:

Boris Johnson could ultimately face prison if he refuses to co-operate with a London Assembly inquiry into his relationship with Jennifer Arcuri today.

Mr Johnson has until today to hand over any texts or emails he exchanged with the model-turned-tech entrepreneur while London Mayor or he could be summoned to explain himself in person.

As Labour called for a full investigation into misuse of public funds, members of the London Assembly’s oversight committee warned the Prime Minister to comply.

He could face a jail term of up to three months or an unlimited fine if he fails to appear if asked.

Committee members and officials will meet today to decide which other witnesses it could ask to appear – potentially including Ms Arcuri.

Tom Copley, a member of the oversight committee, warned: “If we are not satisfied with the answers that Mr Johnson provides, or indeed if he fails to respond, we do have the power to formally summons him as he’s a former Mayor of London.

(Image: ITV)

“It would be a criminal offence were we to issue a summons and for him not to appear before us.”

Downing Street claimed the PM had an extra 24 hours - until tomorrow - to respond as the letter originally sent by the London Assembly went to an incorrect email address. But Assembly insiders confirmed the letter had also been sent to the PM’s constituency office which had acknowledged receipt.

Ms Arcuri refused seven times in her interview to deny a sexual relationship with the then Mayor, but made clear the pair were close. Asked whether she loved him, she replied: “I’ve been asked that many times. I care about him deeply as a friend and we do share a very close bond.”

Under the GLA code of conduct, Mr Johnson had a duty to declare any interest of family or friends so the exact nature of the relationship is seemingly irrelevant.

(Image: AFP/Getty Images)

Shadow Chancellor John McDonnell said: “Regardless of the exact nature of his relationship with Arcuri, it is clear that she and Boris Johnson were close, and that he misled the public when he said ‘there was no interest to declare’.

“The Prime Minister is unfit for office. This morning has thrown up even more questions for Boris Johnson, which can only be answered with a full investigation into the apparent misuse of public funds.”

Labour MP David Lammy added: “Don’t be distracted. The Arcuri story is not about whether Boris Johnson is guilty of cheating on his wife. It’s about whether he’s guilty of criminal misconduct in public office.”

Four separate investigations have been launched into Mr Johnson’s links with Ms Arcuri after it emerged her firm received public money from a City Hall-run organisation and that he over-ruled officials to allow her on a trade mission she was not eligible for.

Both Johnson and Arcuri deny any wrongdoing.
